III.    Facility Identification

The Oberweis facility is located at 951 Ice Cream Drive in North Aurora, Illinois and utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperature of milk, ice cream, and milk products within the facility. 



The NAICS codes for the facility are 311511 and 31152.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to maintain milk and ice cream temperature for storage, packaging, and distribution.   



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. 



The amount of ammonia in the refrigeration system is approximately 17,800 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used for cooling in the freezers, coolers, raw milk tanks, and compressor oil cooling.  The refrigeration system consists of three (3) high stage compressors, three (3) low stage compressors, two (2) evaporative condensers, one (1) -45 recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) -30 recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) +17 recirculator with oil pot and ammonia pumps, one (1) high pressure receiver/thermosyphon, one (1) auto purger, one (1) glycol chiller, one (1) liquid transfer vessel, three (3) raw milk silo evaporators, two (2) surge tanks, two (2) hardening evaporators, one (1) ingredient cooler evaporator, four (4) freezer evaporators, two (2) floor warming heat exchangers, one (1) production ice cream freezer, and seven (7) cooler evaporators.  



The total amount of ammonia present on-site has been estimated at approximately 18,000 pounds.



An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on June 10-12, 2014, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Oberweis has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses, standard operating procedures, and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?    Process Safety Information - Oberweis maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of February 11, 2015.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Oberweis has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of

every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Oberweis conducted a thorough PHA study for the refrigeration system January 6-8 and February 11, 2015.

 

?    Operating Procedures - Oberweis has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.

?    Training - Oberweis has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

?    Management of Change - Oberweis has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 

?    Pre-Startup Review - Oberweis has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Oberweis has developed a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  

?    Contractor Qualifications - Oberweis has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injur

y and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Oberweis and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Oberweis has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 

 

?    Compliance Audit - Oberweis has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Oberweis PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on June 10-12, 2014.  

?    Hot Work Permits - Oberweis has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Oberweis reviewed their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system on June 10-12, 2014.



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Oberweis facility has not experienced any accidental anhydrous ammonia releases, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Oberweis has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  



The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E.

bers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Oberweis operations. Oberweis is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Oberweis.  



XI.    Management Program

Oberweis has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Teetee Roberts Brown, Plant and Fleet Maintenance Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.



Steps to Improve Safety: 

We constantly strive to improve safety of our process using recommendations developed through the prevention program and a program soliciting suggestions from our employees.  Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. Emergency Response Plans, ammonia detection systems. local protective alarm systems and continued OSHA training are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at our facility. 



In addition, the facility will continue to operate and maintain the system in accordance with IIAR Guidance and will continue to implement its OSHA PSM Program in conjunction with the Risk Management Program.
